s.text: Since legal services people often think of themselves as "progressives" who don't need further education on issues of inclusion, making diversity work within programs is not easy and requires the support and the guidance of committed leaders.
Indicators of success -- Money is available to implement innovative diversity agendas and model projects.
A "best practices" clearinghouse is developed where programs share ideas on diversity successes.
Indicators of success -- Salaries and compensation packages are competitive with other nonprofit and public interest organizations.
After prioritizing their primary issues, conferees then listed indicators by which success in achieving diverse communities of justice could be defined.
Indicators of success -- Our senior management includes more women, gays, lesbians, people of color, older people and people with disabilities.
Indicators of success --Boards contain representatives from a greater variety of groups.
Indicators of success -- Money is available to implement innovative diversity agendas and model projects.
A "best practices" clearinghouse is developed where programs share ideas on diversity successes.
Indicators of success -- Salaries and compensation packages are competitive with other nonprofit and public interest organizations.
After prioritizing their primary issues, conferees then listed indicators by which success in achieving diverse communities of justice could be defined.
Indicators of success -- Our senior management includes more women, gays, lesbians, people of color, older people and people with disabilities.
Indicators of success --Boards contain representatives from a greater variety of groups.

Participants agreed that in order to identify and serve groups that remain isolated, we need to broaden our language bases, bring more qualified support staff to our programs, use community leaders and be sensitive to tension between disenfranchised communities.

However, there was an awareness of the need to hire nonlegal staff from the communities being served and this meant that staff workforces often consisted of male, white attorneys and female paraprofessional staff.
National, state and local program boards reflect the diversity of the communities they serve.

Programs are now expected to serve gay, lesbian and transgendered persons, persons with AIDS, children, homeless people, more immigrants (many of whom do not speak English and have complex problems), persons with disabilities, unemployed persons, people of color, rural and urban low-income people, people from depressed areas, and those with mental illness.
We should be particularly careful not to refer clients elsewhere merely because their issues or situations are unpopular.

A core group can begin the work, but structural and programmatic changes -- mentoring, opportunities to talk about real problems and see solutions implemented, power sharing, diverse boards of Directors, new definitions of leadership --will be necessary to achieve lasting change.

A core group can begin the work, but structural and programmatic changes -- mentoring, opportunities to talk about real problems and see solutions implemented, power sharing, diverse boards of Directors, new definitions of leadership --will be necessary to achieve lasting change.

A core group can begin the work, but structural and programmatic changes -- mentoring, opportunities to talk about real problems and see solutions implemented, power sharing, diverse boards of Directors, new definitions of leadership --will be necessary to achieve lasting change.
Women, senior citizens and the working poor still need our services, but new groups have emerged.

The client community included a high number of welfare recipients, was majority white and female with some regional differences and included some undocumented individuals, elderly, non-working poor and prisoners.
There will be more women, children and employed people along with those with mental health needs.
Seeing opportunities for advancement and leadership positions in programs is critical to retaining women, people of color and other individuals who contribute to a diverse staff.
There will be more women, children and employed people along with those with mental health needs.
Seeing opportunities for advancement and leadership positions in programs is critical to retaining women, people of color and other individuals who contribute to a diverse staff.
Many conferees believe that increasing salaries and benefits and developing loan forgiveness programs will go a long way to attracting a more diverse staff.

Program staff and stakeholders are engaged in a full range of client services, address a full-range of legal problems, and have assumed the responsibility to create greater access and capacity to solve them.

Since legal services people often think of themselves as "progressives" who don't need further education on issues of inclusion, making diversity work within programs is not easy and requires the support and the guidance of committed leaders.
Helping staff and boards arrive at a common vision necessitates honest and sometimes difficult conversations.
Conferees believe that programmatic growth rests on a common definition and vision of diversity and earmarking resources so that goals are attained.
Other than that, little attention was given to retaining and promoting people of color, women, people with disabilities and others who reflected the client community.
Other than that, little attention was given to retaining and promoting people of color, women, people with disabilities and others who reflected the client community.
Other than that, little attention was given to retaining and promoting people of color, women, people with disabilities and others who reflected the client community.
Other than that, little attention was given to retaining and promoting people of color, women, people with disabilities and others who reflected the client community.
Seeing opportunities for advancement and leadership positions in programs is critical to retaining women, people of color and other individuals who contribute to a diverse staff.
Indicators of success -- Our senior management includes more women, gays, lesbians, people of color, older people and people with disabilities.
Today's diversity approaches stress inclusion of people of color, people with disabilities, gays, lesbians, older people and women.
Other than that, little attention was given to retaining and promoting people of color, women, people with disabilities and others who reflected the client community.
Indicators of success --Boards contain representatives from a greater variety of groups.
National, state and local program boards reflect the diversity of the communities they serve.

A core group can begin the work, but structural and programmatic changes -- mentoring, opportunities to talk about real problems and see solutions implemented, power sharing, diverse boards of Directors, new definitions of leadership --will be necessary to achieve lasting change.
Each board is required to have a standing committee to monitor board and program diversity.
Building and retaining a diverse staff and board is a major challenge for most programs.
Helping staff and boards arrive at a common vision necessitates honest and sometimes difficult conversations.
Building and retaining a diverse staff and board is a major challenge for most programs.
Recruitment and retention efforts often reflect the importance of a diverse workplace and the commitment of board and staff to this value.
Building and retaining a diverse staff and board is a major challenge for most programs.

Although there was concern about diversity, there was neither real dedication to making it happen nor any real accountability with one exception -- the importance of hiring African American attorneys and having African American representation on boards in regions where African American populations resided.
Program Boards
Building and retaining a diverse staff and board is a major challenge for most programs.

After identifying the benefits and challenges of focusing on diversity and developing strategies to maximize the benefits and overcome the challenges, participants identified internal and external issues that they wanted to spend more time discussing.

On a broader level, conferees agreed that we must work to ensure that both individual state justice communities and the broader national counterpart becomes more diverse, inclusive and multiculturally competent.

On a broader level, conferees agreed that we must work to ensure that both individual state justice communities and the broader national counterpart becomes more diverse, inclusive and multiculturally competent.
Each group was then asked to answer the same set of questions about their particular era.
